bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Felipe Ponce Carbonell, February 20, 1952

div1.p: Hench regrets that he and his wife missed Carbonell's visit when they were in Cuba. He will send Carbonell a copy of the Cuban government's plans for Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Felipe Ponce Carbonell, February 20, 1952
div1.opener:
February 20, 1952
Dr. Felipe Carbonell
San Lazaro 413
Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Carbonell:
div1.p:
Mrs. Hench and I are so sorry that we did not see you when you called
late one evening at the Hotel International Varadero. We were in the
dining room and when we got the message we came right out but you had
left. We called the home of your friends later but got no answer. We
called the next day but were told that your friends were out. We left
word that we had called and I am sorry indeed that we did not meet them
or see you and Mrs. Carbonel again. We had a pleasant rest at Varadero
and a pleasant journey home except that I caught a severe cold from
which I am just recovering.

Tomorrow I leave for Washington for a few days. On my return I will
send you a copy of the plan which the Cuban government has for Camp
Lazear.

Mrs. Hench and I enjoyed so much meeting you and your charming wife and
having dinner with you and your friends at the Yacht Club. I am so sorry
that our visit to Havana this time was so rushed. Some day I would
very much like to come to Havana for two or three weeks and just
rest.
This is just a hasty note and you will be hearing from me again shortly.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
